messages.content:
You are a systematic literature review (SLR) screening assistant.


DOMAIN: AI/ML/DL applications in ophthalmology and eye diseases.

RELEVANT DISEASES:
- Diabetic Retinopathy
- Glaucoma
- Cataract
- Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD)
- Retinal disorders (retinopathy, retinal detachment, etc.)
- Ophthalmic conditions (keratoconus, dry eye, etc.)
- Any eye/vision-related diseases

RELEVANT TASKS:
- Diagnosis
- Detection
- Classification
- Severity grading
- Prediction
- Segmentation
- Screening

RELEVANT METHODS:
- Artificial Intelligence (AI)
- Machine Learning (ML)
- Deep Learning (DL)
- Neural Networks (CNN, RNN, Transformers, etc.)
- Computer Vision
- Image Analysis


================================================================================
TASK: Evaluate this paper ABSTRACT for inclusion.
(This paper passed title screening)
================================================================================

TITLE: Detection and Classification of Retinal Red Lesions via Regional Spatial Transformations and Neural Network
ABSTRACT: The worldwide loss in human vision is primarily associated with Diabetic Retinopathy (DR). It occurs due to accelerated levels of blood sugar thereby causing perforation, bulging and leakage of retinal blood vessels (BVs). DR commences with the emergence of small blood spots on the retinal surface known as Microaneurysms (MAs) that are subsequently transformed into heavy blood deposits called Hemorrhages (HGs). This paper proposes an optimized and computationally inexpensive digital image processing (DIP) technique for detection and classification of 'Retinal Red Lesions' (RRLs) i.e. MAs and HGs using green channel of the digital fundus images. The basic essence of the proposed technique revolves around regional spatial transformations detection performed through region based spatial filtering, matching features and neural networks classification. The proposed technique comprises of five main stages i.e. Pre-processing, Regional Spatial Transformations, Optimization, Features extraction and Classification. Speed Up Robust Features (SURF) algorithm has been used for features selection \& extraction while Feed-forward Back-propagation Artificial Neural Network (FFBP ANN) has been used for classification. The proposed technique has been successfully applied on commercially available digital fundus image data-set and has yielded 98.4\% 'Sensitivity' (SE), 94\% 'Specificity' (SP) and 98\% 'Accuracy' (AC). The SE, SP and AC have also been compared with other RRLs detection methods and has shown highly promising and encouraging results.

================================================================================
SELECTION RULES (BE INCLUSIVE - DO NOT MISS RELEVANT PAPERS):
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Abstract_Selected
IF ANY of the following is TRUE:
- Abstract confirms AI/ML/DL method for eye disease
- Abstract describes automated diagnosis/detection for ophthalmology
- Abstract mentions dataset of retinal/fundus/OCT images with ML analysis
- Abstract is UNCLEAR but suggests AI application in eye care
- Abstract describes deep learning model for any eye condition

OUTPUT: Abstract_Deleted
ONLY IF the abstract CLEARLY confirms:
- This is a review/survey/meta-analysis paper (not primary research)
- No AI/ML/DL methodology is used at all
- The disease is NOT eye-related
- The paper is editorial/commentary/opinion only

================================================================================
IMPORTANT: When abstract is missing or unclear, SELECT (Abstract_Selected).
We prefer false positives over missing relevant papers.
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Respond with EXACTLY one label only (no explanation):
Abstract_Selected
OR
Abstract_Deleted

YOUR RESPONSE:
